title: Football Four: Will Tua Tagovailoa injury impact College Football Playoff race?
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg provides his opinion of the top three programs in the history of college football. USA TODAY

High ankle sprain. Out “a week or two.”

Those words from Nick Saban, describing what he knew of the injury suffered by Tua Tagovailoa, sent people immediately to the calendar: Alabama plays Arkansas. Then a bye week.

Phew!

Will that be enough time for healing before the big bracket-buster with LSU? Probably so, and we all hope so — but the point here is, even as the Football Four remains unchanged this week, everything can take a scary turn with an ankle.

Even without Tua, Alabama beat Tennessee, because of course. But just outside the bracket, there was a radical twist (Wisconsin, what?). And who would even try to predict the next one? The events of the last couple of weekends might simply be foreshocks. So let’s enjoy a season that, even with a lot of familiar names in and just beyond the bracket, has at least shown potential for chaos.

Winners and losers: Week 8 in college football led by Wisconsin, Oregon

Week 8 observations: Wisconsin exposed as fraud in title chase and that could hurt Big Ten

As always, remember we pick the bracket as if the season was over today.*

Football Four

1. Ohio State – The Buckeyes are big and fast and very complete, as Northwestern found out Friday night. Given developments elsewhere, Ohio State looks clearly like the best team in the Big Ten … and beyond.

2. LSU – Joe Burrow set a new school record for TD passes in a season (in the seventh game), which is an illustration of his superlative play and of how LSU has emerged from the Stone Age. Auburn’s defense gets the next shot at slowing LSU.

3. Oklahoma – Thankfully no one was hurt when the Sooner Schooner tipped over. But the football team was never in danger of that from West Virginia. Jalen Hurts had a very big day as Oklahoma hung half a hundred.

4. Alabama – Fire up the cigars, fellas, Tua’s going to be fine! (Or so we’re told.) Despite the lopsided final score, the Crimson Tide didn’t exactly cruise against Tennessee. But assuming Tagovailoa can get healthy in these next couple of weeks, Bama remains on track for a Big 12-style shootout with LSU.

Alabama quarterback Tua Tagovailoa walks off the field during the game against Tennessee. (Photo: Vasha Hunt, AP)

Four More**

5. Clemson – Trevor Lawrence’s decision-making remains occasionally baffling. But the Tigers had plenty of, uh, punch anyway in another lopsided ACC win, this time at Louisville.

6. Penn State – White-outs in Happy Valley are so, so cool, huh? The Nittany Lions couldn’t put Michigan away, and got a little lucky — but they won, and they’re unbeaten.

7. Notre Dame – After an idle weekend, the Irish head to Michigan. It’s not the massive showdown we might have anticipated a few weeks ago, but that’s not Notre Dame’s fault.

8. Georgia – In a steady rain, the Bulldogs finally found the end zone to pull away from Kentucky. But it took a very long time. And although the dismal weather was a very good excuse, Georgia’s issues remain real, and pressing.

A Few More After That***

Oregon – With each win – including a rally to win Saturday at rival Washington — losing that 21-6 lead against Auburn back in the opener becomes more regrettable. But these Ducks have a real shot to get back into the Football Four conversation.

Florida – It didn’t come easy at suddenly solid-ish South Carolina, but the Gators rebounded from the loss to LSU. Up next? A weekend off, followed by a little meeting in Jacksonville with Georgia that could decide the SEC East.

Auburn – A trip to Arkansas — 51-10, just a little tune-up — provided the perfect bounce-back after that loss to Florida a couple of weeks back. Now the Tigers can turn their full attention to LSU.

Baylor – Matt Rhule’s Bears are 7-0 … and if you questioned the Bears before (soft nonconference schedule, some fortunate wins in Big 12 play)? A very, very impressive performance to beat Oklahoma State in Stillwater. Don’t look now, but they’re likely to be 9-0 for what would be a huuuuuuge home game against Oklahoma.

Futile Four****

Tennessee – The Vols actually played fairly well in Tuscaloosa. But trying to pull within one score, Jarrett Guarantano fumbled trying to extend the ball across the goal line … and it was returned 100 yards for a touchdown … and Jeremy Pruitt went off on the QB, including a tug on his facemask … and it was all so Tennessee.

Michigan – Remember when the Wolverines were in the preseason Top 10? Fun times — but these are not. Credit Michigan for scrappily hanging tough with Penn State, but the goal was not scrappy, hanging-tough losses.

Wisconsin – Just when we all thought the Badgers were real, genuine Football Four contenders, they lost to Illinois. It could be worse (could’ve lost to, say, Rutgers) — but it could not be much worse. Ugh.

Miami – Yeah, it took a fake punt and a fumble recovery and a blocked field goal (along with other missed field goals) to lose to Georgia Tech in overtime. But Miami just lost to Georgia Tech in overtime. The Manny Diaz era is off to a very, very shaky start.

* The season is not over today.

** Don’t be worried that your team sits just outside the cut. This is a weekly snapshot. And what do we know, anyway?

*** See the previous note, but it’s OK to be slightly concerned or very angry. But what do we know, anyway?

**** No note necessary.
description: Tua Tagovailoa's ankle injury could be a problem for Alabama if it lingers as the Crimson Tide have LSU on the horizon in early November.
